CHRON-ENTRY.CHRON-TEXT: The Act of Consecration of the cathedral in the Spanish town of Urgell referred to the six parishes of Andorra—the Count of Urgell had assumed suzerainty over Andorra following the fracturing of the Frankish realm.
The Count of Urgell ceded the six parishes of Andorra to the Bishop of Urgell.

The Count of Foix, a French nobleman whose territory included much of the Pyrenean region near Andorra, laid claim to the parishes; he gained recognition of certain rights, but the dispute remained a source of conflict.

A Pareatge (contract or feudal agreement) was signed, sponsored by the King of Aragon, providing for Andorran independence, under the joint sovereignty of the Count of Foix and the Bishop of Urgell, who were to be paid tribute in alternate years.
A second Pareatge was signed, which confirmed the agreement of 1278 and first referred to the sovereigns of Andorra as the Coprínceps (Co-Princes).

The Co-Princes granted an Andorran request for the formation of a representative body for the debate of local issues; the Consell de la Terra (Council of the Land, later the Consell General de les Valls d’Andorra—General Council of the Valleys of Andorra) comprised four members from each parish, elected by the heads of the leading families in that parish.

Henry of Bourbon, who had inherited the title of Count of Foix, ascended the French throne as Henry IV; the French monarch, therefore, became one of Andorra’s Co-Princes (Henry’s son and successor, Louis XIII, reaffirmed Andorra’s status).
The proclamation of a republic in France left the title of French Co-Prince unclaimed, provoking Andorran fears of subordination to Spain.
Napoleon Bonaparte, who had proclaimed himself Emperor of France, issued a decree by which he assumed the title of Co-Prince of Andorra.
With the final restoration of a republic, the President of France became the French Co-Prince of Andorra.
Local defiance of the episcopal Co-Prince was provoked by his attempt to ban the vital tobacco trade.

A Russian émigré, Boris Skosirev, attempted to proclaim himself King Boris I of Andorra, with some influential local support. The Bishop of Urgell sent troops to remove Skosirev from the Principality and the General Council was dissolved by the Andorran judicial authorities. The French Government subsequently sent forces to maintain order and the General Council was re-established.
Women’s suffrage was introduced; in the following year the voting age was lowered from 25 to 21 years.
A seventh parish, Escaldes-Engordany, was created and the membership of the General Council was correspondingly expanded from 24 to 28.
An executive body, known as the Govern d’Andorra (Government of Andorra) was formed from within the General Council, with Oscar Ribas Reig as Cap de Govern (Head of Government).
Ribas was forced to resign upon the failure of his plan to introduce income tax. He was replaced in May by Josep Pintat Solans.
Pintat was re-elected to the post of Head of Government, following a general election the previous month.
Following a general election in December 1989, the General Council elected Ribas to his second term as Head of Government.

Andorra’s first Constitution was promulgated, following its approval by 74.2% of those participating in a referendum held in March. The Co-Princes remained nominally sovereign, political parties and trade unions were legalized and proportional representation was introduced for the election of 14 of the 28 members of the General Council. Ambassadors were exchanged with France and Spain.
Andorra was admitted to the United Nations.

Ribas’ taxation and budget proposals were defeated in the General Council and a motion of no confidence in the Government was passed; Ribas resigned the premiership and was succeeded by Marc Forné Molné, who formed a minority Government.

At a general election, Forné’s Unió Liberal (UL—Liberal Union) won 18 of the 28 seats in the General Council and returned to power; Forné formed a new Government, with an increased number of ministers and portfolios.
The Partit Liberal d’Andorra (PLA—Andorran Liberal Party, formerly the UL) won 15 of the 28 seats in the General Council at a general election. Forné was re-elected Head of Government by the Council.
Joan Enric Vives i Sicília succeeded Joan Martí Alanis as the Bishop of Urgell and episcopal Co-Prince.

The PLA secured 14 seats in the General Council, while the Partit Socialdemòcrata (PS—Social Democratic Party) won 12 and a coalition of two centrist parties took the two remaining seats. A new PLA Government took office on 8 June under Albert Pintat Santolària.
Nicolas Sarkozy succeeded Jacques Chirac as President of the French Republic and French Co-Prince.

At the general election the PS became the largest party in the General Council for the first time, winning 14 of the 28 seats; the Coalició Reformista (CR—Reformist Coalition, led by the PLA) took 11 seats and Andorra pel Canvi (ApC—Andorra for Change) won three. Jaume Bartumeu Cassany, the leader of the PS, took office as Head of Government on 5 June.
ApC announced that it would not support the Government’s budget for 2010 in the General Council.

At a general election, prompted by the Government’s failure to secure sufficient support for its budget, Demòcrates per Andorra (DA—Democrats for Andorra, the successor alliance to the CR) won an overwhelming majority, securing 20 seats in the General Council. The PS retained just six seats, while the remaining two were won by a local conservative group, the Unió Laurediana. Antoni Martí Petit, the leader of the DA, was inaugurated as Head of Government on 12 May.

The Andorran Government signed a formal monetary agreement with the European Union (EU), which declared the euro to be Andorra’s official currency and permitted the Principality to issue its own euro coins from 1 July 2013. (Owing to bureaucratic delays, the introduction of the Andorran-minted euro was postponed.)

At a general election the DA retained its majority in the General Council with 15 seats. Liberals d’Andorra, a new grouping established by former PLA members, secured eight seats, while a coalition between the PS, Greens and independents won three, and newly formed Socialdemocràcia i Progrés d’Andorra (Social Democracy and Progress) secured two. Martí remained in office as Head of Government.

The Government assumed control of Banca Privada d’Andorra (BPA), the Principality’s fourth largest bank, following allegations by financial authorities in the USA that it had been involved in money laundering activities.

The Government signed an agreement with the EU that aimed to reduce tax evasion by allowing the exchange of information on residents’ financial assets and income. The regulations came into force in 2018.
Emmanuel Macron succeeded François Hollande as President of the French Republic and French Co-Prince.

At a general election the DA remained the largest party with 11 seats on the General Council, but failed to secure a majority. The PS and Liberals d’Andorra won seven and four seats, respectively, and smaller parties and independents won the remainder. Xavier Espot Zamora, former Minister of Social Affairs, Justice and the Interior, took office as Head of Government on 16 May.
French President Macron made an official visit to Andorra, the first such visit since 2014.
Andorra formally requested to join the International Monetary Fund.
The Government introduced measures to contain the spread of the coronavirus disease COVID-19.
A new tourist tax came into force. The levy would be charged on all foreign nationals staying in tourist accommodation in the country for the first seven days of their stay.
